utterances: But later they were made in rubber, inflatable.
And they looked like the real thing.
After the war, Kelly lived in Paris.
Art historian Sarah Rich says he'd walk around snapping photographs.
Not photographs of famous places like the Eiffel Tower or anything like that, but photographs just of an alleyway.
Or a plain old window or the side of an unassuming building.
And would see in that photograph a square.
Kelly would use that black square as the basis of a painting.
Now, you don't need a photo to paint a black square.
You just need a ruler.
But Ellsworth Kelly wanted to bring scraps of the world almost mystically onto his canvas.
He pulled out shadows and shapes down into abstractions, monochromes, just one really strong, pure bright color.
Kelly said that came from his boyhood in New Jersey surrounded by nature.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED BROADCAST)
I've always been a colorist, I think.
I started when I was very young, being a birdwatcher fascinated about the bird colors.
The way Kelly used colors made them feel almost alive.
Just to face a giant, red rectangle by Ellsworth Kelly is to come to red in a fresh and profound way.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED BROADCAST)
I feel that I like color in its strongest sense.
Red, yellow, blue, black and white was what I started with.
When Kelly moved to New York in the 1950s, abstract expressionism was all the rage.
He did not fit in, says Sarah Rich, with all the cooler-than-cool artists flinging paint at canvases or dripping it or standing in it.
He was really not interested in their corny expressionism and epic self-importance.
All of that stuff just seemed burdensome and dull.
Forging a new aesthetic language in that environment was not easy, Kelly said.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED BROADCAST)
It was a very hard job, doing it all myself, getting to where I am.
Where Ellsworth Kelly was when he died was a universally recognized master of contemporary art.
He influenced minimalism and pop art with his bold, spare paintings, drawings and sculptures, which are in virtually every major museum of modern art.
When Ellsworth Kelly was 90, NPR asked what he enjoyed most about being very old.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED BROADCAST)
Oh, dear (laughter).
I feel like I'm 20 in my head.
My painting makes me feel good.
And I just feel like I can live on.
If you just keep doing, keep working, that - maybe that's possible.
Ellsworth Kelly came about as close as anyone could to making that possibility real.
Neda Ulaby, NPR News.
We want to turn now to a new look at another ongoing issue that's getting more attention, the reentry of newly released prisoners.
Every year 600,000 inmates leave state and federal prisons.
The Obama administration is trying to make it easier for them to reenter society.
This week Attorney General Loretta Lynch toured a prison in Alabama to talk about the thinking behind those efforts.
